Home > Travel Destinations > 5 Must To See Tourist Attractions In Nova Scotia Canada 5 Must To See Tourist Attractions In Nova Scotia Canada By admin on July 4, 2015 Pin It 
Peaceful and pretty, Nova Scotia is the second smallest district in Canada. It is a beautiful peninsula lying on the eastern edge of Canada. The lengthy coastline of the province is dotted with sandy beaches, plump islands and fishing harbors. 
The scenery of this region varies greatly and the weather here is pleasantly breezy with a damp climate. Summers are sunny and bright but there are fogs and it even snows during the winter months. Top Tourist Attractions In Nova Scotia 
Some of the must to see tourist attractions in Nova Scotia, Canada are include: Cabot Trail 
This is a 300 kilometer long scenic drive along the northwest coast of Cape Breton Highlands National Park. 
This is a coastal route where you can get the sight of the highest mountains meeting the Gulf of St. Lawrence. Beaches, viewpoints and cliffs offer countless opportunities of capturing stunning photographs. Peggy’s Cove 
Peggy’s Cove is a fishing village that has an old world charm and beauty. This village lies around 43 kilometers south of Halifax, the capital of Nova Scotia. 
One of the most beautiful points for capturing the best photographs is the lighthouse surrounded by wave-battered and stark granite bluffs. Art Gallery Of Nova Scotia 
If you have a look into the permanent collection of the Nova Scotia art Gallery you will be able to get a clear picture of life in Halifax and it also serves as a good method of knowing about the city. Pier 21 
Pier 21 is an immigration museum located on Halifax’s harbor. The museum possesses interesting exhibits revealing interesting stories of the people who passed through this pier. It is truly one of the best tourist attractions in Nova Scotia. Halifax Citadel 
It was a military fort built in the 19th century and is very popular for its lively and beautiful atmosphere. This is an old fort maintaining steep walls and underground rooms that have been stone lined. It has been restored and is considered a site of national significance in Nova Scotia.
